title-group.article-title: Traumatic Pseudoaneurysm of the Posterior Tibial Artery Treated by Endovascular Coil Embolization

contrib-group.aff: Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital, Stanmore, Middlesex, United Kingdom

author-notes.corresp: Dishan Singh, Foot and Ankle Unit, Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital, Stanmore, Middlesex HA7 4LP, UK; e-mail: dishansingh@aol.com.

abstract.p: Pseudoaneurysms of the posterior tibial artery are rare, but a high index of suspicion should be maintained in evaluating patients who present with a painful swelling after arterial trauma. We report a case of a posterior tibial artery pseudoaneurysm in a young patient sustained from a laceration and associated profuse arterial bleeding. Because of the risk of rupture and the presence of an infection and high venous flow, an embolization of the aneurysm proximally and distally was carried out after verifying that distal collateral circulation ensured foot vascularization. Endovascular treatment of a pseudoaneurysm seems to be a safe therapeutic and noninvasive choice, particularly in young patients in whom the presence of collaterals guarantees distal vascularization and in whom the procedure can be safely performed in the presence of a superficial wound infection.
Levels of Evidence: Therapeutic Level IV, Case Study

disp-quote.p: “Although some pseudoaneurysms can thrombose spontaneously, they usually need treatment.”

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A pseudoaneurysm, or false aneurysm, is a collection of blood that results from a leakage of blood into the confined perivascular space at the site of a vessel wall disruption as a result of penetrating trauma (eg, laceration1), blunt trauma (eg, ankle sprain2,3) surgery4,5 or endovascular procedures.6 The blood collection is encapsulated by surrounding connective tissue but can expand and compress the surrounding structures (nerves, veins, etc) and may even eventually rupture.1 Although some pseudoaneurysms can thrombose spontaneously, they usually need treatment.

Pseudoaneurysms involving the posterior tibial artery at the foot and ankle level have been reported after stabilization procedures,7 calcaneal fractures,8 after thrombectomy through a Fogarthy catheter4 and after penetrating trauma.9 Pseudoaneurysms of the dorsalis pedis artery have been increasingly encountered as a complication of ankle arthroscopy.10-13 The development of a pseudoaneurysm can also involve either of the terminal branches of the posterior tibial artery, particularly the lateral plantar artery as a consequence of laceration,14 a plantar fasciotomy,15,16or calcaneal osteotomy.17 Pseudoaneurysm of the medial plantar artery has been reported after percutaneous pinning for a Lisfranc fracture dislocation.18

The patient with a pseudoaneurysm will complain of a mass near the site of the trauma that is pulsating, painful, and warm. A thrill may be palpable, and a bruit may be heard. The patient may experience paresthesiae or numbness.

The traditional treatment of pseudoaneurysms has been surgical repair1,4,5 and includes ligation, end-to-end reconstruction, or saphenous vein bypass. Surgery is usually associated with increased morbidity and longer hospital stay and is increasingly reserved as a strategy in cases unsuitable for other modalities such as translumenal and/or percutaneous embolotherapy.1,19

We describe a case of a laceration to the heel area leading to a pseudoaneurysm of the posterior tibial artery and a Pseudomonas wound infection. The pseudoaneurysm was successfully treated by endovascular steel coil insertion. The patient gave informed consent for this case report.

sec.title: Case History
sec.p: A 23-year-old gentleman was wearing sandals at a beach party in South America when he stumbled backward and cut his heel on a shard of glass. There was profuse bleeding and his friend had to wrap a shirt around his foot. His wound was stitched at a local facility, and he was given a course of antibiotics. He then traveled back to the United Kingdom and 5 days later was prescribed flucloxacillin and azithromycin by his general practitioner for a superficial wound infection. A radiograph did not show any evidence of any radio-opaque foreign body. His sutures were removed at 16 days.

He was referred to a foot and ankle surgeon 19 days after his injury complaining of pain, swelling, and a persistent wound discharge as well as numbness on the medial aspect of the right inferior heel. There was a slightly warm, swollen gaping wound (Figure 1). There was no thrill or bruit. Distal pulses were palpable. An urgent MRI without contrast on the same day showed a mass with an extension near the tibial artery. A wound swab was taken, and he was started on high dose flucloxacillin.

caption.p: Swelling and Wound Infection 19 Days Postlaceration With Shard of Glass.

sec.p: An ultrasound revealed an ovoid area of low reflectivity eccentrically located compared with the position of the vessel and showed marked internal color Doppler signal (Figure 2). An irregular low reflectivity laceration could be followed to the region of the mass. The dimensions of mass on this examination were 2.0 × 1.4 × 1.4 cm (longest dimension longitudinally and the appearances were deemed to be consistent with a pseudoaneurysm. A CT angiogram was organized after discussion with a vascular surgeon.

caption.p: A. Real-Time Ultrasound With Color and Duplex Doppler Ultrasound Reveal a Well-Circumscribed Hypoechoic Mass With a Typical Mosaic Pattern of Colors, With Red Indicating the Flow Toward and Blue Indicating the Flow Away From the Transducer. B. Color Doppler Ultrasound 3 Weeks Later Shows That the Pseudoaneurysm Is Totally Replaced by Thrombus With No Blood Flow.

sec.p: The wound swab microbiology results showed a heavy growth of Pseudomonas aeruginosa sensitive to ciprofloxacin and a heavy growth of enterococcus sensitive to amoxicillin. The patient had also noted more pain, more swelling, some tension at the site of the wound, and more discharge. He was started on ciprofloxacin and amoxicillin. His CT angiogram confirmed an aneurysm adjacent to a posterior tibial artery with early venous filling and marked subcutaneous edema but no abscess collection.

Because of the increase in swelling, we decided to proceed to a surgical procedure for the pseudoaneurysm. Because of the presence of a wound infection and early venous filling, the option chosen was that of translumenal coil embolization of the aneurysm. The procedure was carried out by an interventional radiologist 25 days postlaceration through a femoral artery puncture. An intact arterial arcade was confirmed (Figure 3A), and soft platinum 2/4 coils were placed proximal and distal to the false aneurysm and its arteriovenous communication. After 1 week, the swelling had started to reduce, the patient’s wound was nearly dry, and his antibiotics were stopped. An ultrasound scan (Figure 2B) 3 weeks after coil embolization showed that there was no recurrence of the pseudoaneurysm; his wound was completely dry. The patient developed a deep-stitch abscess 5 months after injury, and a deep stitch used to suture the initial laceration extruded itself from the wound. At final follow-up at 8 months, he was asymptomatic, his wound had healed completely, and he had normal pulses.

caption.p: At Arteriography, a Pseudoaneurysm Is Seen at the Site of the Posterior Tibial Artery Laceration. An Associated Arteriovenous Fistula Causes Rapid Filling of the Veins. Stainless Steel Coils Were Placed in the Posterior Tibial Artery Just Proximal and Just Distal to the Pseudoaneurysm. A Postembolization Contrast Injection Showed no Filling of the Pseudoaneurysm and no Further Evidence of the Arteriovenous Fistula.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Complete tears of a blood vessel may not be followed by hemorrhage because of retraction or thrombosis. Continued bleeding because of the lack of retraction, however, may follow partially severed vessels and the resulting hemorrhage is contained by the surrounding soft tissues, resulting in the formation of a hematoma. In cases of pseudoaneurysm formation,1,2,4,5,19 the central portion of the hematoma undergoes recanalization, which essentially “liquefies” the center of the hematoma. This organization, fibrosis, and ultimate recanalization result in a cavity or sac that is in direct continuity with the lumen of the damaged vessel. Once the hematoma becomes encapsulated and forms a mature false aneurysm, continued inflow from the damaged vessel can cause the aneurysm to enlarge and pulsate, usually resulting in localized swelling and increased pain. Arterial flow distal to the false aneurysm is usually maintained.

A traumatic pseudoaneurysm to the plantar portion of the foot can be easily unrecognized1 for weeks when the overall foot perfusion is still well maintained. An untreated pseudoaneurysm can progress to a progressive expansion of the lesion, leading to nerve or vessel compromise; rupture1; catastrophic haemorrhage1; or a compartment syndrome.

The differential diagnoses of a pseudoaneurysm include a hematoma, abscess, arteriovenous fistula, or ganglion cyst. Puncture wounds with resulting pseudoaneurysm formation could be confused with abscess formation because the skin surrounding the lesion in each case may be warm and swollen. There are anecdotes of incision and drainage of such lesions with catastrophic bleeding. Imaging techniques of Doppler ultrasound can detect the size and shape of the mass and determine if there is blood flow into it from a nearby artery, whereas arteriography, CT angiography, conventional MRI angiography, and time-resolved contrast-enhanced 3D MRI angiography delineate the anatomy better.20

Pseudoaneurysms are at risk of rupture1 or fistula formation,21 and a management plan should be made expeditiously to prevent further complications. They can theoretically be treated either conservatively or surgically. Conservative treatment is reserved for asymptomatic patients with small lesions, particularly if affected by several comorbidities or on anticoagulation therapy. These patients will require repeat duplex ultrasound scanning to rule out a progressive enlargement of the pseudoaneurysm. Several different interventional techniques have been proposed to treat a pseudoaneurysm with an evident interest toward minimally invasive modalities.19

Surgical exploration1,4,5 and repair is preferred in the presence of a compartment syndrome, in the presence of distal limb ischemia, for an expanding hematoma, or for active bleeding. However, surgical exploration requires hospitalization and has an associated morbidity.

Embolotherapy19 is becoming the treatment of choice, especially when the patient is not a surgical candidate because of sepsis or other medical conditions and when the pseudoaneurysm has a narrow neck. Embolic materials used for pseudoaneurysms include coils, detachable balloons, thrombin, Gelfoam, and so on. One of the most commonly advocated techniques is percutaneous ultrasound-guided direct injection of thrombin22,23 into the pseudoaneurysm, a technique that has been shown to be more effective than the ultrasound-guided compression therapy in achieving an immediate thrombosis. The advantage of direct percutaneous injection into the pseudoaneurysm is that normal blood flow within the artery is maintained, but an absolute contraindication to the direct injection of thrombin is the concomitant presence of an arteriovenous fistula21 (an abnormal communicating connection between the damaged artery and a vein, which can be seen in about 10% of pseudoaneurysms) because the thrombin could leak in the venous system and cause clots throughout the patient’s body. The arteriogram in our patient had indeed shown early venous filling suggestive of an associated arteriovenous fistula, and we deemed direct thrombin injection to be unsafe.

An alternative less-invasive option is to use an “endovascular” approach—for example, through the femoral artery in the patient’s groin, in which a foam or coil is placed under fluoroscopic angiography. Coils9,16,19 have the advantage of being precisely positioned under fluoroscopic control over radiolucent foams. Radiological coil embolization or endovascular stenting thus allows access to difficult feeding vessels and allows for precise treatment of more complex or established pseudoaneurysms. One of the major limitations of stent graft use is thrombosis; oral antithrombotic medications may provide some protection from this, with clopidogrel and aspirin being the mainstays of pharmacologic therapy. We preferred not to use stenting in this young patient who would have subsequently needed a lifetime of anticoagulation.

When the involved artery is embolized with coils, the artery should be embolized both proximal and distal to the origin of the pseudoaneurysm, so that collaterals do not fill the aneurysm.9 Occlusion occurs as a result of coil-induced thrombosis rather than mechanical occlusion of the lumen by the coil; to increase the thrombogenic effect, Dacron wool tails are attached to coils. The coils are available in many sizes and may be delivered through commonly used angiographic catheters; microcoils are highly thrombogenic, radiopaque, and biocompatible.19

To our knowledge, there have been only 2 previous case reports of endovascular treatment of a posterior tibial artery pseudoaneurysm: one in a patient with Ehlers–Danlos syndrome24 and one in a traumatic laceration where the wide communication of the pseudoaneurysm with the high flow in the posterior tibial artery led to the partial prolapse of the coil within the pseudoaneurysm and subsequent transcutaneous migration of the coil from the thrombus.9 In our case, the deployment of detachable coils distal and proximal to the aneurysm neck for controlled maneuverability was thought to provide a better alternative, with good control and accurate deployment.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Although it is neither prudent nor possible to evaluate each patient that has a foot laceration with arteriography, the clinician should consider arterial injury in the differential diagnosis when a history of significant bleeding is obtained. Moreover, at the time of follow-up and suture removal, the wound should be carefully evaluated. Careful palpation of the wound is likely to reveal the pulsatile character of a pseudoaneurysm; auscultation may reveal a bruit.

Pseudoaneurysm of the posterior tibial artery can cause pain and neurological compression and lead to a rupture particularly if infected. Despite the relatively uncommon presentation of this condition, we do advise that a high degree of suspicion should be maintained in case of a progressively expanding and pulsatile mass, not only after a penetrating trauma to the foot causing a pulsatile bleeding but also following a blunt injury like a severe ankle sprain. A careful neurological and vascular examination must be always performed, and the patient should be referred to an experienced radiologist or envascularly trained vascular surgeon for further investigations like a Doppler scan in suspected cases. Particularly in selected patients, endovascular treatment of posterior tibial artery aneurysms is a useful alternative to a surgical approach.

ack.p: We would like to thank Mr Loh and Dr Lotzof for their clinical input to this case.
